text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of caution to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

RECEIVED
JUN 3 1952
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES OFFICE
PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A TOOL OF RESEARCH USED IN THE RESEARCH

OF THE HISTORY OF SASKATCHEWAN

It is difficult to express a general questionnaire on pioneer life in more than a few words. It is also difficult to answer the same questions in more than a few words. This questionnaire is designed to help you to answer these questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1945, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If there are more than two members of the family who can answer the questions, they should write their answers separately or reply to a separate questionnaire.

GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life," was filled out by persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1945, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If there are more than two members of the family who can answer the questions, they should write their answers separately or reply to a separate questionnaire.

ALL QUESTIONNAIRES

| Questionnaire |
|---------------|
| Pioneer history conditions |
| Pioneer social life, sports and recreation |
| Pioneer economy |
| Pioneer settlement and churchwork |
| Pioneer family experience |

CERTIFICATION OF QUESTIONNAIRE

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Provincial Office. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ... ALBERT ANDREW ...

2. Your address ... ZELMA, B.X., S.A.S.K.

3. Date ... May 42, 1952 ...

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country), PENZANCE, CORNWALL, ENGLAND.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Nicholas Charles Andrew Iron Moulder

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) March 1906

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

   I came straight from my home town, Penzance, to Saskatchewan.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). 21 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West? I thought there would be more and better opportunities for a young man in a young country.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). I already had an older brother in this country and I learnt about the West from him.

RECEIVED
JUN 3 1952
Andrew Albert
Box 84, Selma.

To Sask. - March, 1905

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: ALBERT ANDREW
2. Your address: SELMA, SK.
3. Date: MAY 4, 1905
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): CORNWALL, ENGLAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Nicholas Charles Andrew
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question, if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child")
9. What were your reasons for coming West? I thought that would be best for my family.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Radio? Or government information?) I already had an idea through my family members.

I learned about the West from them.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought it was a good idea to try my luck in a new country, but they also thought it was a terrible long way from home.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I found I really started off by myself, but when I got on the train most of the people who had come from my home town so we fought part of the journey & was again alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Poveshell to Swift Current, Ocean

Swift Current to Halifax. Best of course, no other way in those days.

Halifax to Dundurn, Ocean

Dundurn to ZELMA district, Ocean & Wagon (Of course there was no railway at ZELMA at that time)

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

See enclosed separate sheets.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

See enclosed separate sheets.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In the Zelma district.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Dundurn, Saskatoon, Watson.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Before coming to Canada I worked as a carpenter, joiner & builder, and the first summer I worked at this trade in Saskatchewan, and have worked at different places and times at my trade, but most of the time I have been farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel alone or with a group? (Family, friends, or other group?)

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (Problems you met on the way, interactions with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.)

15. Where did you spend your first winter in Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How do you earn it now?
14. What incidents of the journey? We'd no spare moments.

(Knight spent most on the way; meetings with Radhakrishnan, adventure on the journey; accidents, a little excitement, etc.)

(1) Let me say why Radhakrishnan took these views about 25 or 30 young girls and of whom the same age, I would imagine they were from some 6 or 7 schools, these girls were not the students to see the new arrival in this country, and you can not give information as to the correct remarks & etc. that would be forward from me to another within young people meet in this way. (Signed handwritten name and signature)

(2) When at midnight Radhakrishnan there were 3 girls who had come to the station to see the — (signature unreadable).

Great hope our U.S.A. More 3 girls heard on their hearts and felt this evening station and we didn't expect to see them any more back, close to the station there was a tall, huge light was mounted by the side and on the far side there was a house, we could see the lights shining through the window, and what was a tall man outside, and as our train slowly pulled away we caught sight of three girls send away in train heading across the lake towards their home, it was the first time I have ever seen, and it was kept hidden in my memory for 45 years. I shall often think about it and talk to friends about it even after...
14. What methods of the journey? (Not to give names.)

(Knight goes out on the way; meeting with Braden's advance)

(1) All the journey, accidents, a little excitement, etc.

25 or 30 young girls all of whom are about

and they were known to be about the same age, I would

not be able to tell them apart even though there were

more out the station to see that they arrived at this country,

and you can not guess immediately as to the correct

name of each other without the proper phone call to announce

within thirty-five minutes in this way! (Handwritten phrase)

(2) When at Newcastle Roadway Station there will be great work

and come to the station to see the — train come in.

Great expectations that these girls had on their hearts

and kept this waiting until we didn't want expect

it was almost more than what else is the station then

were a fair stage both remarkable by time and on the

for and three were a person because she could see the

visible changes through the window, and that was a

full moon outside, and no new trains usually handled

away the freight except of those three said arm in arm

standing across the Lake (Handwritten Phrase) But now

the finished flight 9 hour trip near end of the day

right back in my memory for 45 years. I heard often

throughout 9 months God's name at dawn of the dawn plane
(3) Off our head of our journey we were going through heavy thunderous country. If we say that on the turn and we had our misfortune after, our delay came and there was a Bear over there, and immediately one young fellow who had a right knowledge of the place took the gun and fired at the Bear but missed the Bear. But the thunderous turned the subject of the right and could have to bring and hold him not to do that again. For the next third night's house there was no threat and you might have known that thing and then you would be in trouble.

(4) When was known satisfied for weeks as what nothing is let another turn happen if it was not a chance to get out and gather sticks and small pieces of wood to find in the house which was on the house inside them, where there was thick for us to do some cooking or such as keeping Bacon & Eggs and for making tea etc.

But the thunderous got us anxious early and late long as we did not go forward. But on evening the Bear came by they did not realize that the morning there was no more, within the middle of the town.

They saw the Bear leaving down close upon them. There was no time to handle or to turn back they had
(2) All our hearts of love yearning for new glory through
heaven's tenderest sympathy. If we ever feel on this earth
we have heard the message often, surely they will come
and find their place there, and immediately if not
young followers who heard a reply, "Praised be Thy name!"
the great multitude and found at the throne the names
of those that had been delivered from the hand of the
reaper and counted them to him and told him not to
rise that again, for the second time might have been
a moment in their death and yet might have been
saved then and now in eternity.

(3) When men tremble stricken for sinless or who nothing
in that matter know, how is it that men must continue
to put out and gather stalks and small pieces of wood
to fuel in the flame which was on the divine candle
then, what times will there be to do some
cooking or work as playing? But even a rope used for
making the rope
But one thought not a certain activity and fine care
as when their own mind would forget itself off the
tears to gather provisions. Instead of evening the tears
now by they did not realize that the morning
hours was so near, when the multitude of the tears
they knew the tears leaving them alone upon them
there was no time to hesitate or to turn back. They had
to keep on going or else they might have been struck. When they were safely on the other side of the train they looked underneath the Box cars and saw that our or this train had begun to move so they started to run in the same direction as fast as their legs could carry them. We told the conductors about these two boys. Our train was moving very slowly and when we were clear of the other train he (the conductor) stepped our train and the two boys closed in what might have been a tragedy ended all right. These two boys were very tired and played out after their hard run, but now I would imagine much nicer boys next time. I bet they looked after they landed. Nothing very exciting about these stories but they were the only things out of the ordinary that occurred on my journey West.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Salt Lake City?

My first stop was at Regent, here I stayed just one night and I must put in a good word right here for the Salvation Army.

I was standing on the Station Platform looking around. Picture a young lad of just 21 years arriving at a strange place. I didn't know a soul here and didn't know hardly which way to turn. Then a man approached me in Salvation Army uniform and asked me if I had just come out.
To keep me going no end they thought to any keen interest.

When they were employed in the other work of the team

they looked anxiously at the Ban base and over their

heads at what didn't seem strange to me so they started

to turn into the same direction so that as their eyes

could carry them, we could see something very clearly and when

we came close of the other time, he (the traveller)

stopped our things and the two dogs admired us.

What might have been a trip ended all expectations

after two days and every travel and played and

after they heard some words about I couldn't make

sense of what they said. They were the only things that

were there around them.

15. Where did you find anything when you arrived in

London? How long was it?

My friend stayed near Regent's Park. It stayed

right next to the Salvation Army. It was

a nice place to stay. It was a bit

strange place. It wasn't known to

many people. It was a hard place to come and

within a few minutes I found myself there.
from the Old Country (he guessed this when he noticed
the steamship labels on my Portmantries (Indicat)
and also asked me if I had any place to stay.

It was supper time and the night was not far off. I told him that I was an absolute stranger
to the place. He then took my heavy Portmantries
(Indicat) and said you just come along with me
I'll take you to a good place and he came did.

It was a boarding house that he took me to. There
was a long table in the dining room, seated at
the table were several young ladies and I believe
that were some young ladies there also, a place
was set for me but I was too tired to eat
after my long journey. The kind Landlady
noticed this and asked me if I would like
to go to my room. I said I was weak, all right
she said come along and get into bed and in
about 5 minutes I will bring up a little lunch
for you, and this she did. I shall never forget
her kindness. She could not have treated me any
better had she been my own dear mother.

Therefore my first experience on landlady on
South African soil was the meeting of these two
very noble christian people, an officer of the
Salvation Army and the kind Landlady who was
no doubt a member also of the Salvation Army.
I have great respect for the Salvation Army
they are doing a very noble work.
from the old churchyard he passed that within the woodland
the streamside coals on any Rendamnstown (Guthrie)
and why would me if I had any talent to stay
for more than three and the night was not far
to the place. At then took my driving Rendamnstown
(Shepherd) and every year come when nights are
but take me to a good place and the same side
of me a thousand times that the teeth me to place
were a long while in the churchyard same, waited at
the meet there twenty and three also a little
after my journey. At third Sheard took
not for some but 9 came the third to see
it go to him twice. The armed come along and said
about 6 minutes 9 worth telling and a little count
for you, mind this is not. G which never forget
she had she been Ben
perhaps my first friend
Shepherd's name was the only thing I could hear
my noble shepherd's feet, 17th police of the
Guthrie's thing and he heard something make more
no doubt a member also of the Guthrie's thing
& there great respect for the Guthrie's thing
they are doing a very well work.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

For many years I wrote to my parents every week, after that not quite so often but I always kept in touch with them and did not keep them waiting too long for a letter.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

We were married in Saskatchewan on the sixteenth day of December 1912.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Not that I know of.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

One brother came here in 1905 first worked at Brandon Man., as a carpenter, then came to the Selma district and started farming.

Another brother came out 3 or 4 years after and worked in Winnipeg.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

There are many, many events that stand out in my memory of the pioneer days. Please refer to question 39 also I will send you a letter explaining things more fully.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We traveled about to Dundurn 30 miles west of here and got our provisions from there we would make about 4 or 5 trips a year with team & wagon, also I used to drive by horse & buggy about 10 miles to serve in a school house about 4 or 5 times a year taking my Victoria along and playing the hymns for the service.

Most of the visiting was done between neighbors within a radius of 4 or 5 miles.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If not married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brotherly, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. In those particular experiences of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? For what reason or travel?
25. When was the first car used in the community?  
   1914

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Dundurn 30 miles West of here

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We continued to trade mostly at Dundurn until a store was built here at Zelma in 1908 by Mr. J. Campbell of Saskatoon.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once or twice a year, refer to question 24

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   When the first store was built in Zelma in 1908

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   About 1912 would perhaps be about the time that we first bought much through the mail order catalogues (Catalogs) and it was mostly dry goods and seed provisions.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1917, Zelma Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I came here with the idea of staying permanently.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

27. Did you continue to take them? (Indicate any changes due to new forms appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

28. How often did you shop in the early days?

29. When did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

30. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what transactions your total purchases were by mail orders and any changes in the purchasing made by mail order since then.

31. What did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When did you make the decision to move?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Not many, but more could not find work back to the W.I.S., and so a few homesteaders sold out to neighbors after proving up and getting their titles.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Not many but very few did, did not return.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My daughter was President of the Homemakers Club in 1945.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

My brother Howard Andrews along with his partner Frank Imholte were the first to break up or turn the first rock on the trail in this town district in 1917. Albert Andrews was the first to play a musical instrument (the violin) at church revival held in the village of Zelma.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

At present C.N.R. line had was in the early days known as the Grand Trunk Pacific line and the towns were named in alphabetical order and a name beginning with "Z" had to be chosen, but no one knows why. It was called Zelma only the one who named it and who that one was nobody around here knows. It was probably one of the railway officials.

* At Gordon Smiths of the Zelma district might have had a few acres broken up before my brother Howard Andrews & his partner Frank Imholte. I am not quite sure about this. Mr. Gordon Smith came into this district in 1904 and was thereafter the first settler here.
5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1934? What reasons did they have for moving?

34. Did any people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

35. Did the people return during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "known" to have or do something in the district officially, combine, organizing the final lodge, etc., (such as create the North American Church along with the South)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (school districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) date and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in name; (5) date and reason for change. Give dates of year name or above in (1), (2), (3).

*Old President C.R. and New Name in the same neighborhood called "Z" had to be changed, but not known why. It was probably out of the ordinary officials' way.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I have written my own reminiscences covering the years 1906 to 1949. There are 175 pages of facts & stories.

Since we are chapters and about 22,000 words in this unit of which I have an old family photographic album containing about 21 photos and I am still collecting old family photos. I will send you a little explaining this part more fully.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?.... (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

I would really like to see you before making any promises.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

One daughter married, name M. Isabel Jean Johnson she has two boys of school age, Robert Earl Johnson and Floyd Edward Johnson. They and M. Earl Johnson, husband of my daughter live here on my farm.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The most important was of course the coming of the railway and the starting of the settlement of Selmore.

Next the Schools, Church and Telephone and now the Electric Power.

______________________________

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

June 3/52

M. O. Johnson Selmore
M. Earl Henriksen Selmore
M. H. Stanford Selmore

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

______________________________
6.

37. Questions regarding historical source materials:

To you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old photos and photographs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old newspapers, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

Please list any such materials you may have and their location.

Would you or the person who owns them either:

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the archives offices at the University in Saskatoon?

(Initiate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live, and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

The most important was the creation of the capital of Saskatchewan, followed by the building of the college of technology, and the establishment of the school board, hospital, and post office.

The Education Board,

the Electoral Board,

the
